facts.text: The appellant is being prosecuted for adultery under section 497 of the Indian Penal Code.
As soon as the complaint was filed, the appellant applied to the High Court of Bombay to determine the constitutional question under article 228 of the Constitution.

The High Court of Judicature at Bombay (Chagla C.J. and Gajendragadkar J.) in Criminal Application No. 345 of 1951, dated 26th June 1951, decided against the appellant but granted a certificate under articles 132(1) and 134(1)(c).

Under section 497, the offence of adultery can only be committed by a man but the woman would be punishable as an abettor in the absence of any provision to the contrary; the last sentence prohibits punishment of the wife as an abettor.
The appellant is not a citizen of India.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 497 of the Indian Penal Code contravenes articles 14 and 15 of the Constitution.
Whether the appellant, not being a citizen of India, can invoke articles 14 and 15.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 497 offends articles 14 and 15 because the offence of adultery can only be committed by a man and the wife shall not be punishable as an abettor.
Article 15(3) should be confined to provisions beneficial to women and cannot be used to give them a licence to commit and abet crimes; prohibiting punishment is tantamount to a licence.
The appellant cannot invoke articles 14 and 15 as he is not a citizen of India.

court_reasoning.text: The provision in section 497 prohibiting punishment of the wife as an abettor is a special provision for women saved by article 15(3); article 15(1) is subject to clause (3).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any special provision for women.

court_reasoning.text: No restriction in clause (3) limits it to beneficial provisions; a provision which prohibits punishment is not tantamount to a licence to commit the offence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: We are unable to read any such restriction into the clause.

court_reasoning.text: Article 14 is general and must be read with other provisions; sex is a sound classification and the Constitution provides for special provisions for women and children; the two articles read together validate the impugned clause.
The High Court held that the appellant could invoke articles 14 and 15 despite not being a citizen.

holdings.text: Section 497 of the Indian Penal Code does not contravene articles 14 and 15 of the Constitution.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned provision defining adultery offence committed only by man and prohibiting punishment of wife as abettor; held valid

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Articles 14 and 15 tested for equality and non-discrimination; 15(3) saves special provision for women; others for jurisdiction and certificate

outcome.summary: The appeal against the High Court's judgment upholding the constitutional validity of section 497 IPC is dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any special provision for women."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Article 15(3) saves the provision exempting women from punishment as abettors

key_quotes.text: The provision complained of is a special provision and it is made for women, therefore it is saved by clause (3).
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Sex is a sound classification and although there can be no discrimination in general on that ground, the Constitution itself provides for special provisions in the case of women and children.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justification under Article 14 read with Article 15
